body: My vote is for RRR (Revert, Release, Revisit), also because of the macos autotools build breakage.

issue.title: win,pipe: ipc code does not support async read
issue.body:
The implementation of IPC pipe in libuv on Windows does not properly support async reading. This means we cannot set the more parameter without likely causing hangs. Sorry this is yet another followup to #4511.

Fixes #4548

body:
locally I see a lot of nodejs tests failing for various reason. One that I noted is this:
```
=== debug test-stdout-close-catch ===
Path: parallel/test-stdout-close-catch
node:assert:90
  throw new AssertionError(obj);
  ^

AssertionError [ERR_ASSERTION]: Expected values to be strictly equal:
+ actual - expected

+ 'EAGAIN'
- 'EPIPE'
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (C:\cygwin64\home\jameson\node\test\parallel\test-stdout-close-catch.js:31:10)
    at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (C:\cygwin64\home\jameson\node\test\common\index.js:493:15)
    at ChildProcess.emit (node:events:518:35)
    at maybeClose (node:internal/child_process:1103:16)
    at ChildProcess._handle.onexit (node:internal/child_process:304:5) {
  generatedMessage: true,
  code: 'ERR_ASSERTION',
  actual: 'EAGAIN',
  expected: 'EPIPE',
  operator: 'strictEqual'
}

Node.js v23.0.0-pre
Command: C:\cygwin64\home\jameson\node\out\Debug\node.exe C:\cygwin64\home\jameson\node\test\parallel\test-stdout-close-catch.js
```
Which makes me worry Windows is mapping this error wrong, causing libuv to need to map it wrong (04a35efe69001a27e177aebde6c8db6f4cca7e4b). This is slated to be fixed in libuv v2, but I'm not sure it can be fixed in v1.
Yes, I was seeing that error locally too. Is it related to any of the changes added for `v1.49.0`?

So I've been investigating this `EAGAIN` error and seems to be caused https://github.com/libuv/libuv/commit/47c833675bef34edcfaccd97a9a21b0d82aa1fc4. I think the problem is that the aforementioned commit was focusing on `ReadFile()` calls, but the failure in the test is generated in a `WriteFile()` call, and in that case it probably matches better with the `EPIPE` error (I couldn't find official documentation about that specific case though). Should we just revert the commit or be more granular on how that error is translated (`EAGAIN` for `ReadFile()` and `EPIPE` for `WriteFile()`) ?

I am reluctant to revert that, as this is a correction for handling a recent set of bug introduced into Cygwin, and that is likely used quite a bit, especially in the nodejs tests. Unfortunately the Cygwin IO implementation is very old and accumulated a lot of bugs recently and would benefit from using something more correctly implemented like libuv--but I digress. But we should potentially investigate whether libuv WriteFile can continue to directly map this to EPIPE, or whether it should in fact need to resubmit it to the write queue (eg if there are multiple active readers when one closes)

Actually, looking closer at the test source, it looks like it may be a test of exactly that recently introduced Cygwin bug, since it mentions spawning a posix shell, and the Cygwin IO is no longer possible to use in non-Cygwin programs, so I think it is likely the failure here is caused by the recent Cygwin bug and was previously being (wrongly) passing due to libuv incorrectly mapping that error
I'm running this test on `cmd.exe` on a Windows VM. I don't know if in this scenario we're dealing with Cigwin at all

Okay, I see the same testing with cmd directly. I was confused because the test says it is mangled for JSON execution, and that does not seem safe for using with either a posix nor cmd shell. I am attempting some local testing, and it looks like if you slow things down in a debugger, it will randomly either fail because it gets EOF (the write was queued then failed later) or EAGAIN (the write failed to be queued) back from this uv_write, either of which is a somewhat sketchy errno mapping (for the write, not a read):
```    case ERROR_BROKEN_PIPE:                 return UV_EOF;```
Seems like the write fix here is to ensure libuv will map both of those errors different for uv_write to mean EPIPE

Discovered some test code online that discusses this: https://gist.github.com/rprichard/8dd8ca134b39534b7da2733994aa07ba#file-namedpipetest-cc-L22-L28

issue.title: win: fix WriteFile() error translation
issue.body:
Translate `ERROR_BROKEN_PIPE` and `ERROR_NO_DATA` to `UV_EPIPE` instead of their default translation, which will be used for the rest of cases.

Refs: https://github.com/libuv/libuv/issues/4548#issuecomment-2383998849

issue.title: Fix type stability of `ReadEachIterator`

labels.name: io
labels.description: Involving the I/O subsystem: libuv, read, write, etc.

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: This change fixes an existing bug

labels.name: failing
labels.description: CI is failing. Needs attention. No need to re-run CI.

issue.body:
Its `eltype` method had an incorrect type declaration. The preexisting tests did not detect this because they check for array equality, where `Any[] == Char[]` is satisfied.

### Before

```julia-repl
julia> x = readeach(IOBuffer(), Char);

julia> eltype(x)
Any

julia> collect(x)
Any[]
```

### After

```julia-repl
julia> x = readeach(IOBuffer(), Char);

julia> eltype(x)
Char

julia> collect(x)
Char[]
```
